stem.paragraph_1: A patient with coronary artery disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and 80 pack-year smoking history presents with acute chest pain, dyspnea, and hypoxia.  EKG is notable for sinus tachycardia and diffuse submillimeter ST depression.  Exam is notable for tachycardia, II/VI systolic ejection murmur at base, and decreased breath sounds throughout the left lung field.  Which following test would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
Which of the following imaging modalities can definitively diagnose aortic dissection?
Which of the following is NOT a cause of cardiogenic pulmonary edema
How can you clinically differentiate septic shock from cardiogenic shock?

options: Only by history alone - they are very similar on exam.
Septic shock patients have high blood pressure and cardiogenic shock patients have low blood pressure.
Septic shock patients have warm extremities and cardiogenic shock patients have cool extremities.
Septic shock patients have high urine output and cardiogenic shock patients have low urine output.

stem.paragraph_1: If you suspect a patient is in cardiac tamponade, what should you do while waiting for the cardiology consultant to arrive?

options: Cross your fingers and hope she hurries up already.
Give diuretics to try to reduce the amount of fluid around the heart.
Give wide open IV fluids to increase preload.
